SARS-CoV-2 has a single-stranded RNA genome with ~30,000 nucleotides that encodes 12 putative, functional open reading frames[13–15]

Manuscript (GISAID). <mark class="stats">Notably, crRNA-N18f targets all 201 genomes, with only one SARS-CoV-2 sequence carrying a single mismatch mutation (Supplemental Table 8)</mark>. This suggests that our approach can robustly target multiple SARS-CoV-2 strains, but also suggests the potential need to use a pool of crRNAs to avoid mutational escapes

All the other 3,108 Coronavirinae complete genome sequences were downloaded from ViPR (Virus Pathogen Resource) database on February 21, 2020. <mark class="stats">After excluding very short genomes, we collected in total 3,051 Coronavirinae virus genomes</mark>. 202 SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences were downloaded from GISAID (Global Initiative on Sharing All Influenza Data; https://www.gisaid.org/)

We developed a full computational workflow to design crRNAs for the Cas13d system. <mark class="stats">To design all possible crRNAs for the three pathogenic RNA viruses (SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV, and MERS-CoV), the reference genomes of SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV, along with SARS-CoV-2 genomes derived from 47 patients were first aligned by MAFFT using the --auto flag. crRNA candidates were identified by using a sliding window to extract all 22 nt sequences with perfect identity among the SARS-CoV-2 genomes</mark>. We annotated each crRNA candidate with the number of mismatches relative to the SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV genomes, as well as the GC content. 3,802 crRNA candidates were selected with perfect match against the 47 SARS-CoV-2 genomes and with ≤1 mismatch to SARS-CoV or MERS-CoV sequences

If multiple crRNAs were tied for targeting the most genomes, the crRNAs were ranked by the length and quantity of stretches of repeated nucleotides, and the lowest ranking crRNA (i.e. the one with the fewest, shortest stretches of repeated nucleotides) was added to the set of minimal crRNAs. <mark class="stats">Using this approach, a set of 22 crRNAs was identified that was able to target all 3150 Coronavirinae virus genomes (including 47 SARS-CoV-2)</mark>. The phylogenetic tree and the associated annotations were generated by the Interactive Tree Of Life (iTOL v5.5; https://itol.embl.de/)

keywords: Prophylactic Antiviral CRISPR in huMAN cells
summary:
Introduction:

The world is currently faced with a pandemic of novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), which is caused by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) and has no vaccine or cure

It is predicted the development of a safe and effective vaccine to prevent COVID-19 will take one year to 18 months, by which time it is likely that several hundreds of thousands to millions of people may have been infected.
The high catalytic activity of Cas13d in mammalian cells provides a potential mechanism for targeting SARS-CoV-2 for specific viral RNA genome degradation and viral gene expression inhibition.
When combined with an effective delivery platform, PACMAN is a promising strategy to combat not only coronaviruses including that causing COVID-19, but a broad range of other genera of viruses

Methods:

Design and cloning of

RdRP- and Nucleocapsid-targeting crRNAs

The crRNA plasmids were cloned using standard restriction-ligation cloning.

The following day, Lenti-X 293T cells were transfected with 27.18 μg of SARS-CoV-2 reporter, 23.76 μg of dR8.91 and 2.97 μg of pMD2.G (Addgene) in 4.5 mL of Opti-MEM reduced serum media (Gibco) with 150 μL of Mirus TransIT-LT1 reagent.

The following day, the cells were transfected with 15 μg pooled crRNAs targeting the IAV genome or non-targeting controls (Supplemental Table 6) in 1.5 mL Opti-MEM reduced serum media and 30 μL Mirus LT1 reagent.

Results:

Computational design and analysis of targetable regions on SARS-CoV-2

To create effective and specific crRNA sequences to target and cleave SARS-CoV-2, the authors first performed a bioinformatic analysis by aligning published SARS-CoV-2 genomes from 47 patients with SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV genomes at the single-nucleotide resolution level.

To test the efficiency of IAV-targeting crRNAs, the authors performed a screen of the crRNA pools in the stable Cas13d A549 cell line to determine which were most effective at inhibiting IAV infection (Fig. 4A).
CrRNA-N18f targets all 201 genomes, with only one SARS-CoV-2 sequence carrying a single mismatch mutation (Supplemental Table 8)
This suggests that the approach can robustly target multiple SARS-CoV-2 strains, but suggests the potential need to use a pool of crRNAs to avoid mutational escapes

Conclusion:

DISCUSSION AND PERSPECTIVES

CRISPR-Cas[13] emerged as a natural bacterial defense against bacteriophages, a powerful antiviral system that is able to use sequence-specific crRNAs to protect host bacterial cells from infections[29].
The authors' bioinformatics analysis suggested a minimal pool of 6 crRNAs able to target over 90% of sequenced coronaviruses

While this strategy is a proof-of-concept and will require further testing using replication-competent SARS-CoV-2 viruses and validation in animal models before clinical tests in humans, it represents a unique approach to implement a rapid and broad antiviral defense in humans against emerging pathogens for which there are no effective vaccines.

The authors' PAC-MAN strategy represents a potentially powerful new approach for inhibiting viral function and replication, and the authors envision it could be useful for a diverse array of circulating and emergent viral threats

claims: We demonstrate a CRISPRCas13-based strategy, PAC-MAN (Prophylactic Antiviral CRISPR in huMAN cells), for viral inhibition that can effectively degrade SARS-CoV-2 sequences and live influenza A virus (IAV) genome in human lung epithelial cells

Whereas traditional vaccines work by priming the human immune system to recognize viral proteins or weakened viruses and decrease viral entry into cells8, the alternative antiviral approach we propose here relies on a CRISPR-based system for recognizing and degrading the intracellular viral genome and its resulting viral mRNAs (Fig. 1B)
In this work, we developed a Prophylactic Antiviral CRISPR in huMAN cells (PAC-MAN) strategy as a form of genetic intervention to target SARS-CoV-2, IAV, and potentially all sequenced coronaviruses
We demonstrated the ability of our approach to cleave SARS-CoV-2 fragments and to reduce the replication of IAV in human lung epithelial cells

We argue that this approach, in which the lentivirus-derived RNA serves as a PAC-MAN target prior to lentivirus integration into DNA, mimics the crRNA targeting conditions that would apply for natural COVID-19 infection

Our results revealed similar patterns to our SARS-CoV-2 transfection experiments, with the best groups (G4, G5, G8) able to repress their reporters by 69%, 71%, and 60% (p = 7x10-6, 10-3, 3x10-6 for G4, G5, G8, respectively) (Fig. 3C). qRT-PCR analysis also showed consistent results, with G4, G5, and G8 repressing 70%, 68%, and 49% of RNA abundance (p = 8x10-8, 4x10-6, 10-4 for G4, G5, G8 respectively) (Fig. 3D)
We found that the RdRPtargeting crRNAs were able to repress SARS-CoV-2-F1 GFP by 81% (p = 0.01), while Ntargeting crRNAs were able to repress SARS-CoV-2-F2 GFP by 90% (p = 5x10-4) (Fig. 3E, S3A)
We examined the percentage of cells that were mNeon positive for each segment-targeting crRNA pool and calculated the fold-change compared to cells transfected with a pool of non-targeting crRNAs)

We found that just two crRNAs could target ~50% of coronavirus genomes, including those causing COVID-19, SARS, and MERS; 6 crRNAs were able to target ~91% of coronavirus genomes; and 22 crRNAs covered all sequenced coronaviruses with no mismatches (Fig. 5B, Supplemental Table 7)
As a resource, we provide a map to show how our top 6 crRNAs (PAC-MAN-T6) targeted the coronavirus phylogenetic tree (Fig. 5A, red box)
We demonstrated that Cas13d-based genetic targeting can effectively target and cleave the RNA sequences of SARS-CoV-2 fragments and IAV in lung epithelial cell cultures
For both SARS-CoV-2 and IAV, we found highly conserved regions of the viral genomes to target with Cas13d

While we demonstrate that the PAC-MAN system is able to exhibit strong repression of viral sequences in an in vitro setting, it must be coupled with an effective in vivo delivery system for therapeutic use
Here we have demonstrated a genetic strategy that is able to target highly conserved regions, which would be expected to make it much more unlikely for the virus to escape inhibition through mutation

As a further advantage, we demonstrate a potential pan-coronavirus strategy to target not only viruses that circulate in humans, but also those that currently are found in animal reservoirs that might transfer to humans to cause disease
We developed a full computational workflow to design crRNAs for the Cas13d system
findings: Our bioinformatic analysis showed a group of only six crRNAs can target more than 90% of all coronaviruses
We found that the RdRPtargeting crRNAs were able to repress SARS-CoV-2-F1 GFP by 81% (p = 0.01), while Ntargeting crRNAs were able to repress SARS-CoV-2-F2 GFP by 90% (p = 5x10-4) (Fig. 3E, S3A)

We performed microscopy quantification of mNeon+ cells and found that mNeon expression was reduced by 62% (p = 10-5) and 73% (p = 5x10-9) with an MOI of 2.5 and 5, respectively, with S6-targeting crRNAs (Fig. 4C)
key_statements: The world is currently faced with a pandemic of novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), which is caused by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) and has no vaccine or cure

Since coronaviruses causing COVID-19, Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) are able to suddenly transfer to humans from diverse animal hosts that act as viral reservoirs, there is a pressing need to develop methods to combat other potential coronaviruses that may emerge in the future[1–3]

The Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 life cycle is likely similar to closely related coronaviruses such as the virus that causes Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, in which the virus enters the cell, releases its RNA genome into the cytoplasm, and synthesizes negativesense genomic and subgenomic RNAs from which viral mRNAs and a new copy of the positive sense viral genome are synthesized (Fig. 1A)[6,7]

We developed a Prophylactic Antiviral CRISPR in huMAN cells (PAC-MAN) strategy as a form of genetic intervention to target Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2, Influenza A virus, and potentially all sequenced coronaviruses

The two highly-conserved regions respectively contain the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRP) gene in the polypeptide ORF1ab region, which maintains the proliferation of all coronaviruses, and the Nucleocapsid (N) gene at the 3’ end of the genome, which encodes the capsid protein for viral packaging
CRISPR Prophylactic Antiviral CRISPR in huMAN cells is capable of inhibiting coronavirus fragment expression in human lung epithelial cells

To evaluate whether Cas13d is effective for targeting Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 sequences, we created two reporters expressing synthesized fragments of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 fused to GFP (SARS-CoV-2-F1 and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2-F2; Fig. 2B, Supplemental Table 3)
We created a stable A549 cell line expressing Cas13d through lentiviral infection, followed by sorting for the mCherry marker that was co-expressed with Cas13d (Fig. 2C)

We transfected or transduced the SARSCoV-2 reporters into Cas13d A549 cells that had been transduced with pools of four CRISPR-associated RNAs targeting either RNA-dependent RNA polymerase or N gene regions (Fig. 2D, see Methods)

We chose to evaluate the effectiveness of our system using a pool of CRISPR-associated RNAs, since in the context of live viral infection, this would prevent the possibility of escape from inhibition due to a mutation involving a single CRISPR-associated RNAs target site

We observed that most RNA-dependent RNA polymerase-targeting CRISPR-associated RNAs pools were able to repress reporter expression to some extent compared to the control, and one pool targeting the middle of the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2-
We independently validated the performance of adjacent CRISPR-associated RNAs pools when Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2F1 or -F2 was introduced via lentiviral transduction

We argue that this approach, in which the lentivirus-derived RNA serves as a Prophylactic Antiviral CRISPR in huMAN cells target prior to lentivirus integration into DNA, mimics the CRISPR-associated RNAs targeting conditions that would apply for natural COVID-19 infection

Our results revealed similar patterns to our Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 transfection experiments, with the best groups (G4, G5, G8) able to repress their reporters by 69%, 71%, and 60% (p = 7x10-6, 10-3, 3x10-6 for G4, G5, G8, respectively) (Fig. 3C). quantitative real-time PCR analysis showed consistent results, with G4, G5, and G8 repressing 70%, 68%, and 49% of RNA abundance (p = 8x10-8, 4x10-6, 10-4 for G4, G5, G8 respectively) (Fig. 3D)

We further validated the effectiveness of Cas13d-mediated repression of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 reporters by co-transfecting each reporter with a pool of 5 CRISPR-associated RNAs tiled along the whole fragment, compared to a pool of 5 non-targeting control CRISPR-associated RNAs (Table S2)

We found that the RdRPtargeting CRISPR-associated RNAs were able to repress Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2-F1 GFP by 81% (p = 0.01), while Ntargeting CRISPR-associated RNAs were able to repress Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2-F2 GFP by 90% (p = 5x10-4) (Fig. 3E, S3A)

Our analysis revealed that Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 inhibition was more sensitive to CRISPR-associated RNAs concentration in our samples, while lower Cas13d expression only moderately decreased inhibitory activity (Fig. S3B)

Maintaining a high level of CRISPR-associated RNAs concentration is likely a determining factor for more effective Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 sequence targeting and cleavage. These data together suggest: 1) Cas13d Prophylactic Antiviral CRISPR in huMAN cells can be an effective system to target and degrade Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 sequences in human cells and 2) proper design of CRISPR-associated RNAs are important for obtaining a high efficiency of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 inhibition

In contrast to Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2, which has only a single, continuous RNA genome, the Influenza A virus genome is contained in 8 negative-sense RNA segments, in which each plays an important role in packaging the viral RNA into budding virions[16,17]

To create CRISPR-associated RNAs targeting a broad range of Influenza A virus strains, we aligned all complete Influenza A virus genomes retrieved from the Influenza Research Database and searched for the most conserved regions (Supplemental Table 5)
Our analysis and the work of others showed that the segment ends are highly conserved for all 8 segments[16–21]
Using sequence representation from ~140 different strains of influenza, we designed CRISPR-associated RNAs that could be robust across as many different Influenza A virus strains as possible

Our bioinformatics analysis resulted in 6 CRISPR-associated RNAs targeting highly conserved genome regions for each of the 8 Influenza A virus segments, for a total of 48 CRISPR-associated RNAs (Supplemental Table 6)

To test the efficiency of Influenza A virus-targeting CRISPR-associated RNAs, we performed a screen of our CRISPR-associated RNAs pools in the stable Cas13d A549 cell line to determine which were most effective at inhibiting Influenza A virus infection (Fig. 4A)

Two days after CRISPR-associated RNAs transfection, the Cas13d A549 cells were challenged with PR8-mNeon, a strain of H1N1 Influenza A virus (A/Puerto Rico/8/1934) engineered to express the mNeonGreen gene, a fluorescent reporter protein at an multiplicity of infection of 2.5 or 5.026–28

We examined the percentage of cells that were mNeon positive for each segment-targeting CRISPR-associated RNAs pool and calculated the fold-change compared to cells transfected with a pool of non-targeting CRISPR-associated RNAs)

There is a possible trend of greater inhibition at lower viral titers, suggesting that Cas13d Prophylactic Antiviral CRISPR in huMAN cells could be a effective strategy for prevention of new infections, which typically occurs from exposure to a low level of virus

We performed microscopy quantification of mNeon+ cells and found that mNeon expression was reduced by 62% (p = 10-5) and 73% (p = 5x10-9) with an multiplicity of infection of 2.5 and 5, respectively, with segment 6-targeting CRISPR-associated RNAs (Fig. 4C)
The design of a strategy that could broadly prevent and target viral threats, including all coronavirus strains that currently reside in animals, would be a valuable resource
We asked whether it is possible to design a minimal number of CRISPR-associated RNAs that could target a majority of known coronaviruses found in both humans and animals
We refined our list to define the smallest number of CRISPR-associated RNAs that could target all known coronavirus genomes with zero mismatches

We found that just two CRISPR-associated RNAs could target ~50% of coronavirus genomes, including those causing COVID-19, Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome; 6 CRISPR-associated RNAs were able to target ~91% of coronavirus genomes; and 22 CRISPR-associated RNAs covered all sequenced coronaviruses with no mismatches (Fig. 5B, Supplemental Table 7)
We provide a map to show how our top 6 CRISPR-associated RNAs (PAC-MAN-T6) targeted the coronavirus phylogenetic tree (Fig. 5A, red box)

CrRNA-N18f targets all 201 genomes, with only one Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 sequence carrying a single mismatch mutation (Supplemental Table 8). This suggests that our approach can robustly target multiple Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 strains, but suggests the potential need to use a pool of CRISPR-associated RNAs to avoid mutational escapes

Prior work showed Cas13a/b systems could inhibit ssRNA viruses including influenza, which is consistent with our observed high efficiency of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 reporter and Influenza A virus inhibition using the Prophylactic Antiviral CRISPR in huMAN cells approach[31]

We demonstrated that Cas13d-based genetic targeting can effectively target and cleave the RNA sequences of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 fragments and Influenza A virus in lung epithelial cell cultures

Our bioinformatics analysis suggested a minimal pool of 6 CRISPR-associated RNAs able to target over 90% of sequenced coronaviruses. While this strategy is a proof-of-concept and will require further testing using replication-competent Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 viruses and validation in animal models before clinical tests in humans, it represents a unique approach to implement a rapid and broad antiviral defense in humans against emerging pathogens for which there are no effective vaccines. For both Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-CoV-2 and Influenza A virus, we found highly conserved regions of the viral genomes to target with Cas13d

RNA-dependent RNA polymerase is responsible for catalyzing the replication of all viral mRNAs and Nucleocapsid binds to genomic RNA, protecting it and serving as one of the two main structural proteins in virions. Targeted inhibition of these proteins could have an outsized effect on disabling virus production and function, in addition to reducing viral load through degradation of the viral genome itself
Remdesivir is already administered for COVID-19 through compassionate use requests, and clinical trials for its use against COVID-19 have already started in the U.S and China
Oseltamivir, is an antiviral medication for treating and preventing Influenza A virus that acts as an inhibitor of NA, thereby preventing the egress of new viral particles[39]

Traditional vaccines rely on priming the immune system through exposure to viral proteins or peptides often derived from surface proteins that exhibit a high rate of mutation, which increased the chances of viral evasion of the host immune response[44]

We demonstrate a potential pan-coronavirus strategy to target not only viruses that circulate in humans, but those that currently are found in animal reservoirs that might transfer to humans to cause disease
